summary: The document comprises memoranda and reports detailing U.S. covert operations and policy discussions on Cuba during the 1960s, under the Johnson administration. It outlines plans, meetings, and decisions aimed at undermining the Castro regime through sabotage, paramilitary operations, and assassination plots, alongside internal debates on the morality and efficacy of such actions.
key_findings: The CIA allocated over $106 million to Cuban operations from 1960 to 1964, focusing heavily on paramilitary actions.
Discussions and plans to assassinate Fidel Castro involved Cuban exiles and the Mafia.
U.S. officials were divided over covert actions against Cuba, with debates centered on legality, effectiveness, and potential international backlash.
The Johnson administration aimed to minimize public attention on Cuba operations ahead of the 1964 Presidential elections to avoid political damage.
Covert operations included attempts to sabotage Cuban imports and employ biological warfare against Cuba's sugar and livestock industries.
Challenges in controlling U.S.-supported Cuban exile groups were noted, with some operations exceeding authorized limits.
